div1.p: Carr expresses his admiration for Henry Carter.

div1.head: Letter from G. Jameson Carr to Laura Armistead Carter, August 28, 1925
div1.p:
Your very kind letter
enclosed with our from your father
came to me as I was starting on a
tour of the Northern cities of Brazil, as
far as Mansos.

I had just time to answer Dr Carter
in regard to Schistomiasis. Mansoni
and wait until my return to answer yours.
It was with mixed feelings that it left
me to made my tour of study.

Your happy pride in Dr Carter's pride
in “carrying on” to the end, gave birth
to a silent vow within myself-
C1
B2
but it also filled me with a realization of
a great common loss which we shall
sustain, and personally, a lasting regret
that should be mine were I not to have
his blessing before his last great
adventure into the unknown.

What the others of us have felt. I know not-
but without the encouragement of his letters
and example in his disheartening fight,
not so much against Aedes Aegypti as
against ignorance and prejudice, I think
I should have given up.

My first meeting with Dr Carter was by proxy
in Mobile, Alabama, in 1923. When I was
inspecting the Anti-mosquito measures in that
city. I had been challenged to find a breeding
place showing larvae, by one of the inspectors
who had worked under your father, (another
Scot. whose name I cannot recall), and had
almost abandoned the search, but finally
late in the day, came upon one, much to my
National brother's disgust, who stamped his
feet and said. “Man you're as bad as
Dr Carter” What greater compliment could
a young mosquito knight have had? in
fact. I felt I had won my golden spurs.
Since then the ideal has been to try and
enumerate.

I have just heard of Darlings death in
beautiful Beyrouth which I know well.
I owe him much and feel his loss very
personally, for it was he who set my feet on
the path, a great gap has been made
in the front ranks

And alas there seems few to take the
places of the great Yellow fever Crusaders.
So few who love the fight for the fights
sake, as they did and do and yet always
kept the Second Commandment as their
watch word.

That I shall, as soon as I reach New York
take my way to Washington as to a
Mecca, needs no saying and that it shall
be to sit at the feet of the man who inspired
and not to lay a humble tribute on a grave,
is my earnest hope.

I cannot express to you how much your
letter meant, and is meaning to me, it was
so thoughtful in the most of your really
sacred labours, and so needed by the one
who received it for the instruction “be not
ye weary with well doing” needs constant
reiteration in this sad land.

I hope shortly to see my other hero Dr White
who is such a Stonewall Jackson to our
small army with the yellow flag he has
given a high significance to that colour.
but for his sake I wish the fight were over in
Brazil.

With sincere and respectful remembrances to
Dr Carter and my best compliments to
yourself.
